name: packetprotector

content:
Here’s a link for MVCC from last night, the internal database checkpointing system used by Oracle and PostgreSQL, etc.

To put things in perspective, UCB Prof & entrepreneur Michael Stonebraker was at the forefront of these developments. Postgres is so named because the first academic db research project called Ingress had already begun commercialization, so they were exceedingly creative in their next name. 🤷🏻‍♂️🙄🤣🤦🏻‍♂️

All this development and research was nearly contemporaneous with the development of TCP/IP and the BSD versions of Unix. Which begat the Unix Wars and which prompted the development of “Unix compatible” Linux.

No Unix Wars, no Linux. Try to imagine that 🤷🏻‍♂️

Heck, MicroSoft was an early leader in Unix systems via their Xenix platform. Oh well … Gates was smart enough to recognize Unix wouldn’t work as a mass market product and they got lucky as fuck with DEC laying off Dave Cutler and the VMS operating system team, which MSFT hired immediately for what we know today as NT. Boom 💥 

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multiversion_concurrency_control
name: Citizen 🇺🇸

content:
Lastly here’s a link for Paxos consensus algorithm.

Famously put into service by Google via their Big Table, Megastore & Spanner subsystems, which allowed for the creation of Gmail and their portfolio of consumer products.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paxos_(computer_science)

content: Good morning ATL BitDevs! Just wanted to make a reminder that TAB Conf is coming up in September, and this year, all content (talks, workshops, builder day tables, etc) is OPEN SOURCE. What does that mean? It means TAB continues to lean into its community-led, grassroots style by letting the plebs build the schedule. If you want to talk about something at TAB, go to the github repo, and use one of the templates to submit content. The org team is actively vetting all submissions from now until Setpember, and as we get closer, they will be selecting the talks that get the most engagement on GH (i.e. emojis, comments, etc). https://twitter.com/tabconf/status/1666824544039108611

content:
Interrupts are defined by Intel, the CPU.

0 - Timer, the heartbeat, the speed. Everything is dependent on this, ie the scheduler etc

1 - Single Step
3 - Breakpoint. CC hex, a single byte op code.

1 & 3 are how debuggers work.

content:
Yeah, most steganography is contained within a single file tho. (At least that is how I have done it in the past) This example takes two hashed values from common looking files to derive a pubkey. Could distribute the files separately in two different secure communication channels and discretely share a pubkey.

I am not saying this is a good thing and is pretty silly. But for the purposes of a CTF challenge, it could be fun!😀

Bryan, I previously DMed this to you but I figured I would share if here for anyone else whos interested:

Heres a list of some companies offering "Linux-native" computers.  Of course, you can always install Linux on pretty much any computer, but when it ships with Linux, you can avoid issues with driver and hardware incompatibilities.  

Tuxedo (this is the brand I recently purchased): https://www.tuxedocomputers.com/en#

System76: https://system76.com

SlimBook: https://slimbook.es/en/store

Star Labs: https://us.starlabs.systems/pages/starfighter

HP has laptops that ship with Linux, plus they recently started developing a specific laptop aimed at developers: https://hpdevone.com/

Dell also offers some of its laptop shipping with Linux:  https://www.dell.com/en-us/shop/dell-laptops/xps-13-plus-developer-edition/spd/xps-13-9320-laptop/ctox13w11p1c4001u

content:
For those attending tomorrows workshop, we will be learning how CoinJoin with Whirlpool, and how to set it up on our Bitcoin node.

Make sure to do the following beforehand so youll be ready for the workshop:

1. Install a Whirlpool-compatible wallet:
 - Desktop: Sparrow
 - Android: Samourai
 - iOS: Bitcoin Keeper

2. Send some Bitcoin to that wallet. During the workshop you will learn how to CoinJoin that Bitcoin using Whirlpool.

3. If you have a personal node, make sure you can access it remotely through SSH.  Alternatively, bring your node to the workshop and we can help you set it up.

If you have any questions, feel free to DM me or @packetprotector
name: Jordan

content:
For those that use Umbrel, make sure to enable "Remote Tor Access" before coming and copy your auto-generated URL.

Once done, I can show you how to install Tailscale (VPN) on your node during the workshop so you can remotely SSH into your node.

content: As I understand it, if we run our own lightning node at the convention, we can balance and everything over a day and only submit changes at the EoD which would result in 1 transaction fee per vendor, but we would need enough BTC in the wallet to be able to float the entire amount. Is that correct?
name: Robert

content: It depends on the software. With Sparrow, I think the only way to do it is by changing the derivation path when importing the key. For example, if the derivation is m/84/0/0, then you would change it to m/84/0/1 to make a sub-account. If using Blockstream Green, I believe you can tap the cog to open up "Wallet Preferences" and then tap the "Create Account" button. I can demonstrate it sometime.
name: Stephen

content:
Not necessarily. The basic gist is this:
  
First, start a lightning node. We can host lightning nodes in the cloud for you at Voltage, or you could set it up yourself using your own cloud provider, or you could even set it up on your own physical device.
  
Next, you need inbound liquidity to start receiving payments. You can easily pay a small fee to have somebody open a channel to you, or a local pleb would probably open a channel to your node just to help you out.
  
Thats all IF you want to run your own infrastructure. You could also just download something like Breez wallet and start accepting lightning payments with that. It even has a little built-in POS terminal.

content:
On Wednesday night, were going to be looking at the leaked Google memo "We Have No Moat" that @ClockworkKat shared with us. This is an interesting piece because it really shows how powerful open source AI models are becoming. What does this have to do with bitcoin? Well, a hackathon kicked off this past weekend called AI 4 ALL. The goal of this hackathon is to integrate bitcoin/lightning with AI applications. As such, I thought this article would be a great discussion piece to get the creative juices flowing for participating in such an event. Have a great Independence Day, and well see you on Wednesday. 🇺🇸
https://www.meetup.com/atlantabitdevs/events/294526783/

I found the code i wrote back in 2019 to build the neural net I mentioned last night. If anyone is interested in what the code for constructing a LSTM neural net using tensorflow, checkout main.py starting on line 81 for code examples of how a neural net can be constructed https://github.com/bnonni/LSTM/blob/master/src/main.py

specifically, line 83 is the input layer followed by multiple hidden layers each with 200 input nodes (the blue circles last night).
